{{See also|Globalization in China}} [[File:Chinese fashion.jpg|right|thumb|366x366px| A Chinese woman wearing traditional clothes and one shopping for modern clothes. The contrast shows that globalization has changed fashion and culture for Chinese women. ]]
The study of the '''impact of globalization on women in China''' examines the role and status of [[Chinese women]] relative to the political and cultural changes that have taken place in the 20th century as a consequence of [[globalization]]. Globalization refers to the interaction and integration of people, products, cultures and governments between various nations around the globe; this is fostered by [[trade]], [[investment]], and [[information technology]].<ref name=Jiang>Jiang, Shiwei. "Global Trade and Its Effects on China's Female Labor Market." In International Studies Association (ISA) Annual Convention, San Francisco, CA. 2013.</ref> <ref name=car>Carnegie Endowment for the International Peace. (2009). ''What is Globalization?''. Retrieved November 26, 2009. Retrieved from www.globalization101.org/What_is_Globalization.html.</ref> Globalization affected women's rights and the gender hierarchy in China, in aspects of domestic life such as marriage and [[primogeniture]], as well as in the workplace. These changes altered the quality of life and the availability of opportunities to women at different junctures throughout the modern globalization process.
The dynamics of gender inequity are related with the ideological principles held by the ruling political regime. The [[History of China#Imperial China|imperial era]] was dominated by the social paradigm of [[Confucianism]], which was a pervasive philosophy throughout the [[Orient]]. Confucian ideals emphasized [[morality]], character, social relationship, and the [[status quo]].<ref name=main>Main Concepts of Confucianism. (n.d.). Retrieved November 28, 2009. Retrieved from http://philosophy.lander.edu/oriental/main.html.</ref> Confucius preached ''jen'' (humanity) and the equality and educability of all people;<ref name=ng>Ng, R.M. (2009). College and character: What did Confucius Teach Us About the Importance of Integrating Ethics, Character, Learning, and Education? Journal of College & Character, vol 10(4), pp 1-7.</ref> Neo-Confucianists and Imperial leaders used his beliefs in social hierarchy, particularly in the family setting, for the physical and social oppression of women. As the Chinese government began to re-assimilate themselves into the global community in the late 19th to early 20th century, it shifted away from conventional Confucian ideals and women's role in society changed as well. After [[Mao Zedong]] established the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1949, a change in traditional gender roles came about. Mao's death marked the beginning of the current [[communism|communist]] administration, and an influx of international communications in the areas of commerce, politics and social ideals.<ref name=sun>Sung, Y. W. (1991). The China- Hong Kong Connection: The Key to China's Open Door Policy. pp. 1-183. New York: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-38245-9}}</ref> Since the 1980s, under the new communist party, the women's rights movement has gained momentum and has become a national issue as well as a sign of [[modernization]].
In rural areas, women traditionally work alongside their family to produce crops like tea and rice. In urban areas, women work in factories, living away from home. Most of these factory workers are young girls who send their income to their families. To help maintain the rights of women in factories, labor unions and organizations were built. In their homes, women take care of their children and cook.
== Western bias == Western scholarship has historically used ideas of [[Hierarchy|subordinance]] and [[Victimology|victimization]] to characterize traditional Chinese womanhood.<ref name="ten" /> These beliefs were largely constructed on the basis of [[Ideology|ideological]] and [[political agenda]]s, and were widely accepted despite their [[ethnocentrism]].<ref name =ten>Teng, J. E. (1996). The construction of the "traditional Chinese woman" in western academy: A critical review. ''Signs'', Vol 22 (1), pp. 115-151.</ref> Early European writings pertaining to Chinese women were produced by [[Missionary|missionaries]] and [[Ethnology|ethnologists]] at the conclusion of the 19th century.<ref name =ten /> The goal of the missionaries was to "civilize China," and highlighting weakness and victimization provided for the continuance of their work.<ref name =ten /> This belief prompted scholars to use female subordination as a means to validate Western ideas about Chinese culture and Confucian principles.<ref name =ten />
In the 1970s, as the [[feminist movement]]s were forming, they began to affect the literature surrounding women in China.<ref name="ten" /> Studies on Chinese women from this period were concerned with women's liberation, and were sympathetic to the feminist movement.<ref name="ten" /> This sentiment largely influenced the topics and methodology of the research.<ref name =ten /> With this shift in perspective, the focus of discourse remained on subordination, [[Patriarch|patriarchal oppression]], and victimization.<ref name="ten" /> These studies examined such issues as foot binding and the [[chastity]] of widows.<ref name =ten /> Literature formulated by feminist writers did nothing to dispel the myth of the weak, subservient woman.<ref name="ten" /> These works provided a new bias that had not before been articulated.<ref name="ten" /> Feminists believed that Chinese women were a part of a "universally subordinated womanhood".<ref name =ten /> This line of thinking illustrates the cultural superiority inherently felt by Western women.<ref name="ten" /> Writings on Chinese woman rarely account for differences in time, [[ethnicity]], [[Social class|class]], region or age, preferring to describe the status of women as a static, unitary fixture of Chinese culture, despite the political and geographic boundaries that defined different regions and the economic and social changes that occurred throughout history.<ref name =ten />
== History of female oppression in marriage ==
=== Traditional roles and Confucianism === From the [[Han Dynasty]] (206 BC-220 CE) until the modern period (1840–1919), scholars and rulers developed a male-dominated [[patriarchal society]] in China.<ref name="Tamney">Tamney, J. B., & Chiang, L.H. (2002). ''Modernization, Globalization, and Confucianism in Chinese Societies.'' Westport, CT: Praeger. p. 130.</ref> Patriarchy is a social and philosophical system where men are considered as superior to women, and thus men should have more power in decision-making than women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rawat|first=P. S.|date=2014|title=Patriarchal beliefs, womens empowerment, and general well-being|url=|journal=Vikalpa|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1177/0256090920140206|via=}}</ref> Confucianism was at the root of the development of the patriarchal society in China, and emphasized the distinctions between the sexes and the roles they have within the family.<ref name="Tamney" /> These ideologies continued through the [[Tang dynasty]] (618-907), and girls were taught from a very young age to be submissive to their fathers, then to their husbands, and later to their sons.<ref name="Tamney2">Tamney, J. B., & Chiang, L.H. (2002). ''Modernization, Globalization, and Confucianism in Chinese Societies.'' Westport, CT: Praeger. p. 131.</ref> During the [[Song Dynasty]] (960-1297), Confucian scholars further developed the patriarchal tradition with more restrictions for females, including foot binding for girls at a very young age.<ref name="Tamney3">Tamney, J. B., & Chiang, L.H. (2002). ''Modernization, Globalization, and Confucianism in Chinese Societies.'' Westport, CT: Praeger. p. 132.</ref>
=== Married life in Imperial China === The traditional [[Chinese marriage]] system benefitted men more than women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Marriage and Inequality in Chinese Society|last=Ebrey|first=Patricia Buckley|publisher=University of California Press|year=1991|isbn=0-520-06930-7|location=Berkley, Los Angeles, Oxford|pages=1|quote=|via=}}</ref> This effect could be seen in monogamy, concubinage, divorce, and the heritage of lineage and property through males.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Marriage and Inequality in Chinese Society|last=Ebrey|first=Patricia Buckley|publisher=University of California Press|year=1991|isbn=0-520-06930-7|location=Berkley, Los Angeles, Oxford|pages=14|quote=|via=}}</ref> After the [[Spring and Autumn period|Spring and Autumn Period]], elite men could take primary and secondary wives, concubines, and maids.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Marriage and Inequality in Chinese Society|last=Ebrey|first=Patricia Buckley|publisher=University of California Press|year=1991|isbn=0-520-06930-7|location=Berkley, Los Angeles, Oxford|pages=29|quote=|via=}}</ref> Ancient Chinese women were denied the right to choose their marriages.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=中国古代婚姻制度中女性的地位|journal=Bulletin of Chinese Language Teaching|volume=Feb.,2016, Vol.878 No.2.}}</ref> Generally, traditional Chinese marriage was organized by the parents of the groom and bride in order to obtain alliances between the two families to ensure the continuance of the family line.<ref name="Tamney4">Tamney, J. B., & Chiang, L. H. (2002). ''Modernization, Globalization, and Confucianism in Chinese Societies.'' p. 133. Westport, CT: Praeger.</ref> The prime mission of a married woman, regardless of her social status, was to bear at least one son in order to carry on the family name.<ref name="Yao4">Yao, E. L. (1983). ''Chinese Women: Past & Present'' (p. 22). Mesquite, TX: Ide House, Inc.</ref> Therefore, women were only valued for their reproduction functions.<ref name="Yao2" /> Three types of marriage dominated in Ancient China.<ref name="Yao">Yao, E. L. (1983). ''Chinese Women: Past & Present'' (p. 17). Mesquite, TX: Ide House, Inc.</ref> The first traditional Chinese marriage type, which originated in the primitive society,<ref>Qixin Chen and Hong Dong. “中国抢婚习俗研究.” In ''中南民族学院学报(哲学社会科学版)''. 1993: 6, pp. 44</ref> was called a "capture marriage," in which the groom would go to his prospective bride's house at dusk to "kidnap" her.<ref name="Yao" /> The second type was called a "purchase marriage," in which women were paid for by their husbands.<ref name="Yao2">Yao, E. L. (1983). ''Chinese Women: Past & Present'' (p. 18). Mesquite, TX: Ide House, Inc.</ref> Once women were purchased, they became their husband's possession and could be traded or sold.<ref name="Yao2" /> The third type was the "[[arranged marriage]]," which could be traced back to the Warring States, emphasized the necessity of parental control and matchmaking institutions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=孟子|last=孟|first=轲|publisher=艺术中国网|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=42|quote=|via=}}</ref> Matchmakers acted as go-betweens for both families.<ref name="Yao3">Yao, E. L. (1983). ''Chinese Women: Past & Present'' (p. 19). Mesquite, TX: Ide House, Inc.</ref> If there was not a matchmaker, the marriage could be deemed unacceptable and could be dissolved.<ref name="Yao3" /> Once two people were married, the wife would leave her family, live with the husband's family, and be obedient to her in-laws as if they were her own parents.<ref name="Yao4" />
During the Chou Dynasty, the upper class considered daughters-in-law as commodities of the husband's parents, not the husbands.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past & Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=24|quote=|via=}}</ref> This meant that wives had to be subservient to parents-in-law.<ref name="Yao4" /> They were expected to have impeccable manners, including refraining from coughing and sneezing in the presence of their husbands' parents.<ref name="Yao4" /> Wives could not leave their rooms or accept gifts from relatives without permission.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past & Present|last=Yao|first=E.L.|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, TX|pages=22–23|quote=|via=}}</ref> Refusal to turn gifts over to parents-in-law lead to physical abuse and expulsion from the family.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past & Present|last=Yao|first=E.L.|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, TX|pages=23|quote=|via=}}</ref> In addition, wives were required to serve in-laws, including helping them bathe, arranging their bedding, and cooking.<ref name="Yao4" /> People placed a strong emphasis on food preparation in Ancient China.<ref name=":1" /> Cooking was one of the most time-consuming tasks for wives because of traditional rituals and high expectations for the taste and appeal of food.<ref name=":1" />
=== May Fourth Movement === [[File:Chinese protestors march against the Treaty of Versailles (May 4, 1919).jpg|thumb|left|alt=protesters at the may fourth movement.|Protesters at the May Fourth Movement]]The [[New Culture Movement|"New Culture" movement]] began in China around 1916 following the unsuccessful activities of the 1911 Revolution to establish a republican government, and continued through the 1920s.<ref name="Asia">Asia for Educators, Columbia University, Initials. (2009). Before and After the May Fourth Movement. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/special/china_1750_mayfourth.htm</ref> The [[May Fourth Movement]], which took place on May 4, 1919, was a demonstration led by students at the National Peking University against the government, in which they protested the abolition of Confucianism and changes in the traditional value system.<ref name="Yao5">Yao, E. L. (1983). ''Chinese Women: Past & Present'' (p. 127). Mesquite, TX: Ide House, Inc.</ref> Many believed that the solution to China's problems would be to adopt Western notions of equality and [[democracy]].<ref name="Asia" /> Since the movement stressed group efforts and [[propaganda]], women were involved in numerous collective tasks such as publication, drama production, and fund raising, which helped them gain more social contact with men and win respect.<ref name="Yao5" />
{{Clear}}
=== Marriage reforms in the Twentieth Century === Chinese modern heterosexual monogamous marriage was officially established with the [[New Marriage Law|Marriage Law of 1950]] after the founding of the People's Republic of China.<ref name="China Today">China Today. (2001). [[Chinese marriage|Marriage law]] Revisions Reflect Social Progress in China. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/English/e2001/e200103/hunyin.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100629155714/http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/English/e2001/e200103/hunyin.htm |archivedate=2010-06-29 |df= }}</ref> The New Marriage Law declared the abolition of the feudal marriage system, which included arranged and [[forced marriage]], male superiority, and the disregard for the interests of children.<ref name="Tamney4" /> This law also asserted the rights to [[divorce]] and embraced the free-choice marriage.<ref name="Hershatter">Hershatter, G. (2007). ''Women in China's Long Twentieth Century.'' (p. 16) Berkeley, CA: University of California Press.</ref> Although progress has been made, Chinese women are restricted by the [[heteronormativity|heteronormative]] and [[hypergamy|hypergamous]] marriage system.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wives, Husbands, and Lovers: Marriage and Sexuality in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Urban China|last=Zhang Jun|first=Sun Peidong|publisher=Stanford University Press, Palo Alto|year=2014|isbn=978-0-8047-9184-7|location=|pages=120|quote=|via=}}</ref> Currently, all Chinese women are still expected to marry a man with superior educational and economic status in their early or mid-twenties.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wives, Husbands, and Lovers: Marriage and Sexuality in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Urban China|last=Zhang Jun|first=Sun Peidong|publisher=Stanford University Press, Palo Alto|year=2014|isbn=978-0-8047-9184-7|location=|pages=120–124|quote=|via=}}</ref> Many well-educated and well-paid urban professional women tend to delay their partner seeking and marriage, which results in a supposed revival of tradition – parental matchmaking.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wives, Husbands, and Lovers: Marriage and Sexuality in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Urban China|last=Zhang Jun|first=Sun Peidong|publisher=Stanford University Press, Palo Alto|year=2014|isbn=978-0-8047-9184-7|location=|pages=119, 124–125|quote=|via=}}</ref> Since Chinese parents generally do not "use a daughter's marriage to build a family network or maintain a household's social status" anymore, this matchmaking is not a forced marriage; it is a suggestion intended to benefit their daughters.<ref>Zhang, Jun, and Sun, Peidong. (2014). Deborah S. Davis and Sara L. Friedman, eds., ''Wives, Husbands, and Lovers: Marriage and Sexuality in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Urban China.'' p. 136. Stanford University Press, Palo Alto. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-9184-7}}</ref>
As a result of these reforms, the roles of wives have changed for both rural and urban women.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past & Present|last=Yao|first=E.L.|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, TX|pages=179|quote=|via=}}</ref> Today, a wife's role is to support her husband and children, not serve her in-laws.<ref name=":2" /> Mothers-in-law have less authority, and married couples are able to have more intimate relationships.<ref name=":2" /> Since the one-child policy was established, urban wives have devoted their time to raising "'the perfect only child,'" so they now exert more effort creating their own families than serving in-laws.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women in China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=48|quote=|via=}}</ref> Despite this focus on children, patrilocal residence increased again towards the end of the twentieth century.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=Women in China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=22|quote=|via=}}</ref> Urban parents have stayed close to their sons to help them find jobs, housing, and services.<ref name=":8" /> Rural women have also gained more autonomy, including the freedom to voice their opinions and desires.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women in China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=23|quote=|via=}}</ref> Wives in the wealthy countryside have demanded construction of mansions for neolocal residences.<ref name=":8" />
== Domestic life of a Chinese woman ==
=== Foot binding === [[File:Natural vs. bound feet comparison, 1902.JPG|thumb|A comparison between a woman with normal feet (left image) and a woman with bound feet]]
[[Foot binding]] is the process in which the arch of a woman's feet is broken and the toes are wrapped up against the foot to create a smaller looking foot with an acute arch.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=94|quote=|via=}}</ref> These "fists of flesh" were seen as attractive and arousing for men and the practice was passed down as a prerequisite to marriage from mother to daughter across [[generation]]s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=94–95|quote=|via=}}</ref> The process of foot binding was painful and often confined women to their rooms.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0-86663-099-6|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=95|quote=|via=}}</ref> Few lower class women were able to have their feet bound because they needed to be able to walk normally to accomplish house work.<ref name=":4" /> Bound feet came to be an indication of [[upper class|high class]] and wealth for women.<ref name=":4" /> Chinese male reformers during the [[imperialism]] period recognized the liberation of the Chinese women as something necessary for their own sake.<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body">Pierce, Steven, and Anupama Rao. Discipline and the Other Body: Correction, Corporeality, Colonialism. Durham: Duke UP, 2006. Print.</ref> The humiliation that China had gone through on an international level was turned on the Chinese "women".<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body" /> Naturally, the foot binding was recognized as "national shame," and people found it as a serious problem to be disappeared, thus raging anti-footbinding campaigns in the 1890s to the 1900s.<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body" /> Moreover, the new government that came in after the 1911 revolution banned foot binding practice.<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body" /> Thus, it started to disappear in the coastal areas in 1900 to 1920.<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body" /> However, the practice was still popular within the interior areas of China till the 1930s and even in the 1950s.<ref name="Discipline and the Other Body" />
=== Changes to customs based on Confucianism === Under Confucianism the typical family was [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] because men had the capability to pass on the family name and carry on the [[Kinship|lineage]] of the [[ancestors]]; women were expected to be subservient.<ref name="Yao4" /> Adoption of Western family values in the twentieth century challenged traditional Chinese values.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese vs. Western Perspectives|last=Zhou|first=Jinghao|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2013|isbn=9780739180457|location=|pages=33|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[Chinese nationalism|Nationalism]] contributed to the changes of customs and status of women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=414–15|quote=|via=}}</ref> Nationalist revolutionary [[Qiu Jin]] promoted feminism through various essays and speeches, as well as through her ''Chinese Women's Journal''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=413|quote=|via=}}</ref> Jin chastised wife beating, female infanticide, arranged marriages, and foot binding.<ref name=":0" /> She eventually began teaching at a girls' school.<ref name=":0" /> Around this time, many other schools for girls opened in China.<ref name=":0" /> This led to increased job opportunities for women in the 1920s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=413–14|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Later, as the Communist regime changed the structure of Chinese society through economic reform, the structure of the Chinese family was altered.<ref name="Guthrie">Guthrie, Doug. (2008). "China and Globalization: The Social, Economic and Political Transformation of Chinese Society". pp. 77- 86. London: Taylor & Francis.</ref> "The Four Olds" (''sijiu'') – old ideas, old habits, old customs, old cultures – were discouraged and were replaced by Communist ideology, particularly during the Cultural Revolution.<ref name="Guthrie" /> The economy was shifted to total government control with few chances to own private property and communal property.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Patricia Ebrey, Anne Walthall, and James Palais|first=|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|year=2009|isbn=9780547005348|location=Boston and New York|pages=461|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[Collectivization]] destroyed "clan-based" systems and had a great effect on motivation of workers and family loyalties.<ref name="Guthrie" />
The traditional social structure was further degraded by the [[Cultural Revolution]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> The [[Red Guards (China)|Red Guards]] turned members of a family against one another as they sought out "class enemies" to be sent for "re-education," ultimately resulting in a loss of family ties.<ref name="Guthrie" /> Women were elevated to equal status as men through a series of laws which prohibited practices such as arranged marriages, [[concubinage]]s, [[dowry|dowries]], and [[child marriage|child betrothals]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> Under these marriage laws, women enjoyed joint property in marriage and could file for a divorce.<ref name="Guthrie" />
As a result of Communist rule in China, the social status of women improved greatly.<ref name="Communism">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Women Under Communism", Facts and Details:China, Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21#02 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |date=2009-11-27 }}</ref> Women were empowered to work outside the home.<ref name="Communism" /> Communist rule also brought about the end of practices such as foot binding, child marriages, [[prostitution]], and [[arranged marriage]]s.<ref name="Communism" /> China has seen a decrease in [[domestic violence]] due to government-supported grassroots programs to counter these practices.<ref name="FactsAndDetails.com">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Women in China" Facts and Details: China, Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |archivedate=2009-11-27 |df= }}</ref> Women in rural areas remain largely uneducated.<ref name="Village Women">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Village Women" Facts and Details: China. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21#02 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |date=2009-11-27 }}</ref>
=== Population control === During the reform period, the Communist regime in China regulated [[birth control]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> The government shaped policies with the intention to develop population science “through selective absorption of Western science and technology.”<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=27|quote=|via=}}</ref> In 1979, the [[Family planning policy|Planned Birth Policy]] was implemented.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Birth Control in China 1949–2000 : Population Policy and Demographic Development|last=Scharping|first=Thomas|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=2013|isbn=978-0-7007-1154-3|location=|pages=4|quote=|via=}}</ref> The Chinese government only allowed one child per Han family, with more children allowed to non-Han families.<ref name=":3" /> Since this planned birth policy was implemented based on local laws rather than on a national population law, the level of birth restriction differed in urban and rural areas.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=27–28|quote=|via=}}</ref> In families reliant on farming for income, the household is the fundamental unit of production, so many rural families would rather pay the hefty fines for excess birth.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=28|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In 2011, city couples who both came from one-child families were allowed to have a second child, while couples in rural areas could have a second if just one of them came from a one-child family.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/14956C3C5EFFAF28?p=AWNB|title=Shanghai Municipal Government: Young Couples Sticking with One Child|last=|first=|date=November 16, 2011|work=China Business News (China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref> In 2013, the further revision of the Planned Birth Policy allowed couples in which either parent had no siblings to have two children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/14B0B267AD5D1D08?p=AWNB|title=Child policy eased, camp abolished|last=|first=|date=December 29, 2013|work=Shanghai Daily (China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref> In 2015, China allowed all couples to have two children, abolishing its decades-long one-child policy for urban families.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/158CAF6871392A70?p=AWNB|title=One-Child Policy Lifted, All Couples Allowed Two Children|last=Xin, Lin and Gang, Wu|first=|date=October 30, 2015|work=Global Times (Beijing, China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Another instance of population control is the prevalence of [[female infanticide]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> People in rural areas practiced female infanticide and selective neglect due to a preference of sons over daughters.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=9780520098565|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=28–29|quote=|via=}}</ref> Since the 1980s, roughly 200,000 female infants would be killed per year because of the preference for male children and the advancement in technologies such as [[ultrasound]], which help to find out the sex of the fetus.<ref name="Guthrie" /> In addition to female infanticide, girls are being unregistered or are abandoned by their families, which stops them from receiving education and legal benefits the government offered.<ref name="Guthrie" /> These methods of controlling population have resulted in a huge [[china gender gap|gender gap]] in China.<ref name="Guthrie" />
== Chinese women throughout the workplace ==
=== History of working women === [[File:Rice fields mazandaran.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Women working in [[Paddy field|rice fields]]]]
In the imperial era, women experienced physical restrictions that limited their social positions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=29|quote=|via=}}</ref> They held jobs that required minimal physical activity like domestic chores and producing textiles to sell or use.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=167–169|quote=|via=}}</ref>
During [[History of the People's Republic of China (1949–1976)|Mao's rule]] (1949–1976), Chinese women were needed for their manual labor for farming and for urban industrialization.<ref name=":6" /> To compensate for their hard work, they were provided access to education and politics.<ref name="Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization">Perry, Susan H. Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization. Retrieved 2 Nov 2009. Retrieved from https://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KwTGhzy305KmJZ25jjkRgHQ1TmFh1gPnhzZGTyCZpv6czQ1GMLf6!101686917!1275526282?docId=5002557820.</ref> The Chinese government supported women's education.<ref name="Yao 1983 174">{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=174|quote=|via=}}</ref> The percentage of girls attending school was 96.2% compared to below 20% before the [[People's Republic of China|People's Republic]] (1949).<ref name="Chinese Women" /> The Chinese government has tried to decrease the number of women illiterates while promoting adult and vocational schools.<ref name="Yao 1983 174"/> The percentage number of illiterates has gone down from 90% in 1949 and 32% from 1993.<ref name="Chinese Women">China Daily. "Chinese Women".Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_aboutchina/2003-09/24/content_24139.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923221936/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_aboutchina/2003-09/24/content_24139.htm |archivedate=2015-09-23 |df= }}.</ref> In the first 30 years of Communist rule women's discrimination was decreasing, but they did not have jobs that had real decision-making power.<ref name="Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization" /><ref name="Working Women in China">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Working Women in China-Facts and Details". Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.</ref>
The Chinese government has made great efforts to achieve a high level of economic status for women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=165–173|quote=|via=}}</ref> Since 1949, with the founding of the People' Republic, the rate for employed women has risen.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=170|quote=|via=}}</ref> Chinese women account for 44% of the work force and 34.5% account for the women's work force in the world.<ref name="Chinese Women" />
=== Rural areas === The key role women have in farming is to maintain ownership of the main sources of production in rural areas.<ref name="Woman-Work115">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 115. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> In traditional China, women were not allowed to own land or property.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=23|quote=|via=}}</ref> Land was inherited through the sons, and if there was no son in the family, it was taken by a close male relative.<ref name="Woman-Work116">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 116. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> In less populated areas, women do more agricultural work than men because of [[shifting cultivation]].<ref name="Woman-Work119" /> In more populated areas, men do more work than women because extensive [[plough]] cultivation is used.<ref name="Women's Role in Economic Development">Boserup, Ester (1970). ''Women's Role in Economic Development'' p. 35. London: Allen and Unwin.</ref> Female involvement is high in the [[Multiple cropping|double-cropping]] rice area.<ref name="Woman-Work119">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 119. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> Other types of work women perform in the countryside include pig and poultry rearing, [[Spinning (textiles)|spinning]], [[weaving]], [[Basket weaving|basket-making]], and other handicrafts. This type of work supplements agricultural income.<ref name="Woman-Work120">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 120. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> [[File:Professional woman.jpg|thumb|299x299px| A professional woman is making a deal with her male client. This shows globalization has increased job opportunities for women in urban China. ]]
=== Urban areas === China's economic policies laid the basis of the [[industrialization]] drive in export-oriented development, and its reliance on low-wage [[manufacturing]] to produce consumer goods for the world market.<ref name="Gender and Change">Lee, Eliza W.Y. (2003). ''Gender and Change in Hong Kong: Globalization, Postcolonialism, and Chinese Patriarchy''.pp. 1-224. UBC Press,{{ISBN|0-7748-0994-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7748-0994-8}}</ref> Young [[immigrant|migrant]] women left their homes in rural settings to work in urban industrial areas.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=1–6|quote=|via=}}</ref> Work included [[export-oriented industrialization]], manufacturing in electronics and toy assembly, sewing in garment production, and mixed assembly and sewing in the footwear industry.<ref name=":5" /> [[Hong Kong]] and [[Shenzhen]] were cities established as centers of export-oriented industrialization, and migrant women workers have made up 70% of Shenzhen's three million people.<ref name="Gender and Change" />
Private sector employers are reluctant to hire women because Chinese law requires that the employer cover maternity leave and childbirth costs.<ref>Tatlow, Didi Kirsten. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/26/world/asia/26iht-china.html?partner=rss&emc=rss "For China's Women, More Opportunities, More Pitfalls."] ''[[nytimes.com]]'', 25 November 2010</ref> However, certain industries prefer female workers for assumed benefits.<ref name=":7" /> For example, the beauty economy, which is defined as "a marketplace in which young, attractive women are used to promote commercial products and services," includes the sales industry.<ref name=":7">Osburg, John (2013). "Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality among China's New Rich", p. 144. Stanford University Press, Stanford. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-8354-5}}</ref> The development of the sales industry has increased job opportunities for women, but women are also restricted to these gendered professions.<ref>Osburg, John (2013). "Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality among China's New Rich", p. 143-182. Stanford University Press, Stanford. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-8354-5}}</ref>
==== Reasons for migrant labor ==== [[File:Seagate Wuxi China Factory Tour.jpg|thumb|180px|Workers perform final testing and [[Quality assurance|QA]] before sending [[Disk storage|drives]] off to customers on its 2.5-inch [[Laptop|notebook]] lines.|left]] A recent phenomenon, the migration of rural Chinese workers began in 1984 when the Regulations of Permanent Residence Registration became less punitive and allowed people to move to find employment.<ref name="Female Migrant">China-Labour. "'Dagongmei' – Female Migrant Labourers." pp. 1-8. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.china-labour.org.hk/en |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027112136/http://www.china-labour.org.hk/en/ |archivedate=2009-10-27 |df= }}</ref> People left rural areas to escape poverty, and females left due to the lack of local opportunities for women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianna M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=36|quote=|via=}}</ref> In the cities, women could find new, low-paid factory-based jobs that did not require highly skilled workers.<ref name=":5" /> According to national statistics, the ratio of male to female migrant workers averages 2:1, and an estimated 30-40 million of the migrant women work in the cities, namely Hong Kong and Shenzhen.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
In the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, females comprised 80% of the workforce and had an average age of 23.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Young female workers are preferred over older females or males for several reasons.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> First, as married women are less mobile, female migrant workers are younger and more likely to be single than their male counterparts.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Young rural women are preferred for these jobs primarily because they are less likely to get pregnant, and are able and willing to withstand longer working hours, have "nimble fingers, and will be less experienced in asking for their [[Statutory law|statutory rights]].<ref name="Female Migrant" /> In many cases, migrant women sign contracts stating that they will not get pregnant within their period of employment."<ref name="Female Migrant" />
In the interest of the family, rural females are sent to find urban employment over male counterparts, mainly to supplement familial income at home and to support the males, who are more likely to attend college.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> The male standard of education in China is higher, particularly when a family is under financial stress, females are more likely to drop out of school to generate income for the family.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Gender Inequality in Education in China: A Meta-Regression Analysis|journal=Contemporary Economic Policy|volume=32}}</ref> Because females have lesser impact on the family's long-term financial stability, their rights for opportunities development are consequently unequal.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> This inequality also reinforces emotional motivations for migration.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 8. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Many women migrate to find personal fulfillment.<ref>Poras, M. (Director). (2013). ''The Mosuo Sisters'' [Video file] In The Mosuo Sisters. Retrieved October, 2016.</ref> Stereotypes in China that developed as a result of globalization portray rural women as "‘backward’" and urban women as "‘modern’".<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 31. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Many people associate modernity with maturity, so rural women migrate to cities to be perceived as mature.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 3. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Migrant women also appreciate the knowledge they obtain (including political- and self-awareness) while living in cities.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 80. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Some women even report desiring to leave villages as a result of boredom with rural life.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 40. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Ideas perpetuated due to globalization simultaneously increased women's intentions to become independent; many migrant workers desire lives separate from those of their families’.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 30. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref>
This new system allowed rural residents to migrate, it did not allow them to change their residence or accept any [[Social welfare|benefits]] in the cities.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Made in China|last=Pun|first=Ngai|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780822386759|location=Hong Kong|pages=115|quote=|via=}}</ref> This resulted in a growing population of migrant laborers without the minimal benefits of residency including medical care, housing, or education.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Many migrant women do not trust the government to protect their rights.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=978-0-8248-4098-3|location=Honolulu, Hawai'i|pages=64|quote=|via=}}</ref> Today, up to 90% of migrants work without contracts, in violation of the [[Chinese labour law]].<ref name="Female Migrant" />
==== Degradation ==== The freedom to display femininity and gender equality seem incompatible in Chinese society.<ref name="Liu 2008 87–92">{{Cite book|title=East Asian Sexualities: Modernity, Gender, and New Sexual Cultures|last=Liu|first=Jieyu|publisher=Zed Books Ltd.|year=2008|isbn=9781842778883|location=London|pages=87–92|quote=|via=}}</ref> Gender equality appeared prevailing only when women were restricted to desexualization in the Mao era.<ref name="Liu 2008 87–92"/> [[Chinese economic reform|Opening up policy]] guarantees women's freedom for resexualization, but it simultaneously brings back gender inequality.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asian Sexualities: Modernity, Gender, and New Sexual Cultures|last=Jackson, Liu, and Woo|first=Stevi, Jieyu, and Juhyun|publisher=Zed Books Ltd|year=2008|isbn=978-1-84277-888-3|location=London and New York|pages=87|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Women factory workers are known as "''dagongmei''" (working girls).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Made In China: Women Factory Workers in a Global Workplace|last=Pun|first=Ngai|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780822386759|location=Hong Kong|pages=2|quote=|via=}}</ref> They are traditionally young women migrants who experience a segmented [[labor market]] in informal and low-wage employment sectors.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out To Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianna M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=60|quote=|via=}}</ref> Workers in export-oriented factories receive [[minimum wage]] and minimum [[overtime]] pay, they pay for meals and lodging at the factory, and they pay fines for breaking [[factory]] rules.<ref name=":5">''China Blue''. Dir. Micha X. Peled. Perf. Jasmine Li. 2005. Accessed Web. 20 Nov. 2016. https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/chinablue/film.html</ref> The average daily wage, for a 12-hour day in a toy factory, in the mid-1990s was $1.10 USD for migrant women workers in Shenzhen.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Although migrant workers in China still earn low wages, their average income has increased over the past several years.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/306686/china-monthly-income-of-migrant-workers/|title=China: migrant workers average monthly income 2015 {{!}} Statistic|website=Statista|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> In 2008, the average daily income for migrant workers in China was equivalent to $6.48 USD.<ref name=":9" /> In 2014, the average daily income was equivalent to $13.86 USD.<ref name=":9" />
These conditions create "maximum [[Economic surplus|surplus]] appropriation"; workers' daily lives revolve around factory production and are dependent on the economic conditions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=166|quote=|via=}}</ref> The state disallows local [[unionization]] and has the [[All-China Federation of Trade Unions]] (ACFTU) as the legitimate forum of worker representation.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Without the right to form [[Trade union|unions]] and with the state sanctioned ACFTU, migrant women workers find it hard to effectively gain suitable rights and treatment from the factory management.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> The 2003 statistics from the People's University show 90% of migrants work without contracts, directly violating the Chinese Labour Law.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> According to the ACFTU, migrant workers are owed over 100 billion Yuan in back wages.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
Organizations are now attempting to assist and empower female migrant workers through training and education on their labor-related rights.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=5–6|quote=|via=}}</ref> Legal clinics have begun to assist female migrants in filing claims against employers and local labor bureaus.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> One case of female worker exploitation in the Hua Yi garment factory in [[Beijing]] resulted in mistreatment by management as well as withholding pay for at least 24 women.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> After filing complaints, in collaboration with the Center for Women's Law Studies and Legal Services of [[Beijing University]], the women received 170,000 Yuan in back wages and compensation.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
Relations between workers and employers represent both the immediate need of manufacturing plants for large quantities of low wage laborers, and the insecurities young workers face in relocating long distances to life in factory dormitories.<ref name=":5" /> Hiring single young women serve needs of [[management]].<ref name="Gender and Change" /> The employment of young females allow management to exhibit maximum control and authority over the [[labor force]].<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Compared to older women and male workers, young single women are susceptible to the authority and demands of management.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> The common manipulation of "factory as family" by owners and managers suggests how [[workers]] hold a subliminal status within the factory environment.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Uneven power relations inside the factory result in demands from management for personal services from women workers, from hair washing to sex.<ref name="Gender and Change" />
